text:
The students in Mr. Bernoski’s class play several rounds of the game. At one point in a game, the scores are as follows:

Super Brains: –300

Rocket Scientists: 150

Know-It-Alls: –500

  • Which team has the highest score? The lowest score? Explain why.

The Rocket Scientists have the highest score because they have the only positive score. The Know-It-Alls have the lowest score because they have the negative score with the greatest absolute value (the score furthest left of 0). Students might say that the Know-It-Alls are the most in debt or furthest behind.
• Use equations (number sentences) to describe at least two ways that each team could have reached its score.

Many answers are possible.

Two possible answers for each team’s score are provided.

  • Super Brains: 100 + -250 + -150 = -300; -250 + 50 + -100 = -300
  • Rocket Scientists: 250 + 50 + -150 = 150; 250 + -100 = 150
  • Know-It-Alls: -50 + -200 + -250 = -500; -100 + -250 + -100 + -50 = -500
• Find the difference in points for each pair of teams. How is this information useful to each team?

Rocket Scientists have 450 more points than the Super Brains. (150 - – 300 = 450)

Rocket Scientists have 650 more points than the Know-It-Alls. (150 - – 500 = 650)

Super Brains have 200 more points than the Know-It-Alls. (– 300 - – 500 = 200)

The information tells how many points it would take for the team that is behind to catch-up.
